Please note the following:

• This board desires high quality discussion. High quality posts will be praised. Low quality posts e.g. "Is this paranormal?" or "I am [insert paranormal entity here] ask me anything," etc. will be removed.
• Requests belong on >>>/wsr/.
• Conspiracy theories are welcome, but anything political in nature should be posted to >>>/pol/.
• For everything else, refer to global and board-specific rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Welcome to Divination General! Come here for readings and a discussion of theory/practice.

Every method is welcome: Tarot, Runes, Cartomancy, Scrying, Pendulum, Cleromancy, I-Ching, Oracles, Tasseomancy, Necromancy, etc.

>If you're NEW, please READ the STICKY:
http://pastebin.com/2Wp1Q074

>Recommended /div/ links and books:
https://pastebin.com/sAkg9cMz

>MEGA with Divination Books:
https://mega.nz/folder/Jp8gQD7Q#om_2lEm1GL0qPIpSrQgrvA

>Guides made by some of our readers:
•Rustig on how to start with tarot:
http://i.imgur.com/2rodLWB.png

•Thoth's tarot and rune guide:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ciFuMOVDIkA18d9Rw-Zkklgigx-Y4XzJkGVeMTYWcic/edit?pref=2&pli=1

•Hijinks' revised divination guide:
https://pastebin.com/Gv10KZUA

>Useful tips before posting:
•If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent; same goes for trading.
•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34045601
This fallacy is called begging the question. You are starting with the assumption that such experiences are hallucinatory.

In fact, evidence has suggested just the opposite. People experiencing NDEs sometimes view their bodies from above, and see things they would not have been able to see from the physical perspective of their unconscious body. Why would they see and know these things if they can’t from their body’s angle, and when they should be unconscious anyway?

And in addition, hallucinations can be generalized as experiences that feel as real or less real than reality. NDEs are almost always described as more real than our reality. And often people compare the reality shift to that which people experience when waking up from a dream. In other words, we know dreams are not real since, when we wake up, it is more realistic than the dream. Similarly, people who experience NDEs are often quoting as describing the reality of NDEs as so realistic that not only is the step between reality and NDE greater than the step between dream and reality, but the NDE reality is impossible to put into human language. This simply is not symptomatic of any hallucination we know.
>but what about drugs?
Yes, with drugs like DMT, people report hallucinations that can seem more real than reality. However, firstly, drug-induced hallucinations differ greatly depending on which drug you are using, but none of them come close to matching all the symptoms of an NDE:
>clarity
>belief that it is not a hallucination
>high sense of reality
>consistency across people’s experience
>consistency across belief systems
>high retention of memory after experience
>ego death
Secondly, drug users also get NDEs, and drug users very consistently say that NDEs are way more intense than any drug experience they have had.

Please note what I am hinting at is firstly true wood-turpentine, not mineral terpentine, which is a different thing.
Secondly, it is used in this example by producing a salve that is applied to open wounds to cause them to grow back. I am unaware of what effect it would have if taken internally, I don't think that would work, there's too many heavy organic molecules produced via combustion and distillation.
tl;dr this salve is highly experimental, and I only know of through old folk-tradition, but in theory I can see how there'd be something to it.
It is to the best of my knowledge produced by combining 1 part real turpentine, 1 part 'stove-pipe soot' (And in this context, what we're talking about is that the people who produced this substance all heated their houses and cooked on wood-stoves, burning the same kind of wood as the terpentine was harvested from, and therefore their stove-pipes would have accidentally worked as a sort of crude fractional-still, yielding a great variety of useful organic compounds.), and one part ash from the fires of this process. (I hypothesize that the ash was used to change the PH of the salve, or perhaps served some nano-structural function, but I don't really know.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34042094
>NDEs are real
Near Death Experiences are just that, experiences. The only way to determine whether an experience is real or not is 1) does it have real world effects 2) can those effects be measured? If I tell you I saw a unicorn, that just means I have a story of a unicorn. It doesn't mean I actually saw a flesh and blood unicorn. I would need to provide a flesh and blood unicorn that could be measured and weighed as any other organism to prove it is real. Likewise, the experience of dreaming isn't real, because peoples' brainwaves can be measured and a scientist can determine when a person is asleep by those measurements, and when people are woken up from deep REM sleep they all report seeing and hearing things. Dreams themselves are not real because no one in the room can observe or measure what exists within the dream.

NDEs are not real experiences because people who are not dead cannot observe or measure anything that happens during a NDE. Therefore, either science is not a valid method or NDEs are not real.

I can appreciate the dedication some people have to NDEs. I have had countless dreams, vivid, intense, catastrophic, blissful, etc. I've often times found myself wondering if my dreams are real, but no matter how much I wish they were I have to admit I can't prove it to anyone else. I have no choice but to conclude that NDEs are nothing more than especially intense dreams that happen when a person's body and brain are under an enormous amount of stress. They are profound, they are mystical, but they are dreams. To tell people they shouldn't fear death because they might have a nice dream is absurd.

posts.com:
DAILY REMINDER - GPS absolutely proves globe Earth, rotating Earth, space, orbiting satellites, time dilation (relativity), and gravity.

Flerfers will point to LORAN and claim that GPS could work off of transmitters sitting on the ground, on balloons, or on airplanes. But it cannot.

Why? I'm glad you asked.

In tracking mode GPS receivers use Doppler signal analysis to determine receiver velocity. It is impossible for a transmitter to fake Doppler signal shift to multiple receivers across 360°. If the transmitter was lying about its speed, then the receiver would think that it was moving at high mach based on the incorrect Doppler shift in the signal. And since GPS is computed in 3D space from four satellite signals, if the satellites were lying about their positions (altitudes) the resulting location and altitude on the receiver would be off by thousands of miles.

This means that GPS satellites are provably at orbital altitudes and speeds, because GPS could not function at all if the satellites were lying. And if the satellites aren't lying, then space is real. Orbits are real. But the dome is not real. Not unless the satellites punched through it.

What about Earth's shape? GPS receivers use a spherical model of Earth. If Earth was really flat, then receivers would report altitudes literally thousands of miles off. This means Earth really is a sphere.

Furthermore, both Earth's rotation and time dilation must be accounted for in GPS. If either one was not true then, once again, receivers would give obviously false and useless results. That means Earth really is rotating. And time dilation is real. And if both orbits and time dilation are real, that pretty much guarantees that gravity is real.

No single instrument completely shatters all of flat Earth mythology quite like the GPS constellation. It really is a beautiful thing.

posts.com:
The Box That Killed The Dome

If you remove the lid of a pressurized box of air inside of a vacuum chamber without gravity, the air will violently rush out of the box to fill the vacuum. The air pressure will then be the same at every point in the chamber. It will be the same at the top, bottom, middle, and at all sides. Just like the air pressure in your car tires or a balloon or a SCUBA tank.

This thought experiment debunks the entire flat Earth model. If the air does not cling to the bottom of the chamber, then it certainly would not cling to the bottom of flat Earth. If the air does not leave any part of the chamber still in vacuum, then it certainly would not leave any part of flat Earth in vacuum. And if the air creates equal pressure at all points in the chamber, then certainly the air creates equal pressure at all points in the flat Earth dome.

Yet there is no denying that air thins as you climb in altitude. At 100,000 feet, somewhere near the top of the theorized dome, the air pressure is so low that it is effectively a vacuum.

This alone debunks all of flat Earth.

Note: no flerfer has ever provided a workable answer to this. They immediately sperg out if you even mention it, and rant and rave that the box thought experiment actually kills the globe. The only way they can do this, of course, is to deny gravity. But if gravity doesn't exist then the dome is just as dead. And if it does exist, the globe model works, while the dome remains...dead.

posts.com:
FLERFERS LIE

Take a close look at the attached pic. Flerfers often post it as proof the Earth is flat. Why do I want you to look at it? Because it's a lie.

"The Australian Black Swan" tells you that the maximum line of sight for a 5.5ft tall observer is 2.35 miles. But the cliff is 7.8 miles away. So what's wrong with this flat Earth "proof"? *** Line of sight depends on both observer and target height, as well as on atmospheric refraction. *** The lighthouse is at least 100ft tall which means the visible cliff is at least 400ft tall. LoS for a 5.5ft observer of a 500ft (combined height) target is 35 miles.

What about the oil platforms? Ocean oil platforms have an "air gap" between the ocean and the first deck of 40-60 feet. Observer height was listed as 1ft (camera on the ground?). With a 40ft first deck the line of sight is 10 miles. With a 60ft first deck it's 12 miles. With a 5ft observer and a 60ft first deck it would be 14 miles.

At 6.21 and 9.41 miles you would still see the entire structure above the first deck even if the first deck was only 40ft off the ocean and the camera really was on the ground at 1ft. For the closer platform you would see some structure below the first deck. Note that we see more of the closer rig, proving curvature.

Here's a line of sight calculator: http://www.calculatoredge.com/electronics/lineofsight.htm

>but we're talkin' about muh horizon
>MUH HORIZON IS TOO FAR AWAY!
No it's not. It's between the observer and target in both photos. That's why the observer cannot see the very bottom of the target.

>>34066481
>The Doppler isn't faked. The balloons are stationary
A receiver in tracking mode expects a specific Doppler shift from a GPS transmitter. It can determine receiver movement by the variation from its expectation. If Earth is stationary, and the transmitter is a stationary balloon, and the receiver is stationary, there is NO Doppler shift. Which will make the receiver think it's traveling at mach 11.37, same as what it expects of the transmitter. (Give or take depending on angle.)

Does your car navigation system or phone ever tell you that you are moving at mach 11.37? No? Then the transmitter is not stationary.

Jordan Peterson's framework is rooted in Carl Jung, who's work was a more psychological exploration from people such as Schopenhauer and Nietzsche; the latter two who were very interested in Proto-Christian / Post-Christian Esoteric / East Asian monistic / pantheistic / panentheistic philosophy.

a. Jung believed that the reason why religions stuck around for cultural generations was because we projected our objective, human ideals into idealized figures / deities / myths, and because these human ideals are objective, the same themes / deities / ideas would repeat themselves, which he called "Archetypes". Jung tried to systematize this into a secular, objective philosophy
b. Jung's philosophy would apply this to the field of psychology, seeing that many people had psychological problems because their objective biology / mental state was failing to live up to these ideals which we projected outwards into these religious systems
c. Carl Jung's ideas, while unique, originate in "esoteric" spiritual systems, which were well known for connecting strands of ideas across various spiritual systems, and aren't as dogmatically bound and are way more open to seeing similar concepts in other religions and connecting the dots than mainstream "exoteric" systems (for example, the Hermetics have no problem connecting the divine hermaphroditic Platonic deity with the Primordial Hermpahroditic Adam in Kabbalah or, Adi-Buddha in Tibetan Buddhism, Shiva-Shakti in Hinduism, the Baphomet in Satanism, etc. (see pic related)).

It's evident that Jung was a believer in spiritual realities given his writings on synchronicity.

Carl Jung had a pronounced focus on applying his ideas to Catholic mythology and European folklore, given his familiarity with it culturally and the fact that this would make his work more marketable, particularly in a time where people were more religious and grew up in such an upbringing.

Jordan Peterson, at least from his public speeches, really seems to fundamentally lack familiarity with the sources from which Carl Jung derives his ideas from or even the very logic by which Carl Jung created his ideas; you get hints of it in some of his Disney lectures, but he draws from Jung very dogmatically and often lacks the insight as to why Jung interprets things the way he does.

What Jordan Peterson seems to do is he works from Carl Jung and interprets Protestant Christianity / Roman Catholicism from a Jungian psychological angle, but because he interprets Jung are a purely academic, secular, objective school of peer-reviewed psychological thought, he just puts out Jungian concepts out there as the exclusive, total, and final way to see value in Christianity, irregardless if one believes in it or not.

But him citing Jungian concepts out of the blue with no explanation given, either academically or even with Jung's philosophical arguments, is not really an argument, considering most people are unfamiliar with Jung's work (as they can be incredibly complex for the average Westerner), and even those who are don't really understand Jung's logical thought process. Not to mention Roman Catholicism and Protestant Christianity itself tend to be hostile towards an open, non-exclusive interpretation of the Bible.

>someone who had some severe trauma

The reason is because people who undergo extreme trauma can undergo a dissociative state where they separate from their ego. This puts them into a state of shock where they witness themselves without any sense of control. This can sometimes become a permanent state of detachment, though it's probably very rare, but it can also sometimes lead to the realisation that a person is more than their thoughts, or that there is an intelligence, or identity, within them that is more than their thoughts or their body or what they see or feel. This is not to equate shock or trauma directly with a religious experience, as that's not really true, because the ongoing experience of that similar state is joyful and peaceful, but perhaps when a mind is first ripped away from the body and the ego it can result in some severe shock.

Also, entry into religious experience begins, essentially, with surrender or acceptance of what is. You let go of all that you know, think, feel, believe. This is why those who suffer find God, because they are driven to the point where they either let go or they kill themselves. This is used as an argument against religious experience, as you have done "Oh well they HAD to find something or else what would they have?". But, when you are thirsty you drink. You can seek out the experience yourself without all the suffering, if you want. Ask and you shall receive, they say. People who don't think of asking just don't receive though, do they? Don't discount experiences born from suffering or trauma or poverty.

The NAC Protocol (Updated February, 2023)

Morning

1200mg NAC

Continue daily for a minimum of two months and count out 3 weeks with no die off symptoms prior to moving to the next step.

Maintenance Protocol
__________

Morning

600mg NAC
500mg Slo Niacin (nicotinic acid)
100mg Pterostilbene
250mg Pomegranate Extract (40% EA)
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

500mg Slo Niacin
100mg Pterostilbene
250mg Pomegranate Extract
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

After every 3 weeks on the maintenance protocol, take 1 week off. Continue to use black seed oil during the off cycle.

Fungal die off symptoms may include :

>Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

For each morning and night dose you need a minimum of 40mg Carvacrol. Do not buy a product unless it is listed. Most products are steam distilled but you will want to confirm that.

If your chosen oregano oil contains a higher amount of carvacrol (60mg+ per cap) you'll want to start with 1 cap morning, 1 cap night. If each cap contains less than 40mg, take 2 morning 2 night.

POMEGRANATE DOSING GUIDE

You want a minimum of 100mg Ellagic acid for each morning and nightly dose. If you buy a Pomegranate extract that has 40% Ellagic Acid, that means a 250mg capsule contains 100mg Ellagic Acid.

posts.name: Space Cowboy
posts.com:
NAC, Oregano Oil and Black Seed Oil have all been proven safe in clinical studies.

NAC has shown to be safe in human trials, even in high doses.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33326056/

Oregano was tested in human clinical trials (both Phase I & II) and found to be safe and non-toxic even at high doses.

See Section 4.1 Safety & Toxicty

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/fsn3.2994

See also a 2 month clinical trial on asthmatics.

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ptr.5967

Black Seed Oil and it's primary active Thymoquinone. See:

https://brieflands.com/articles/semj-76453.html

We recommend cold pressed black seed oil, which uses no chemical solvents or heat processing.

https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Vasfiye-Ozyurt/publication/329993761_Cold_press_in_oil_extraction_A_review/links/5c61d58792851c48a9cd3e63/Cold-press-in-oil-extraction-A-review.pdf

Oregano oil at the minimum carvacrol levels of protocol are produced by steam distillation. No additional solvents are required, as it uses vapor condensation to separate the volatile molecules and active compounds.

https://chemdictionary.org/steam-distillation/

Finally, NAC is produced by a reaction between cysteine hydrochloride and acetic anhydride. A LC–UV–MS analysis of NAC shows impurities to be cysteine, cystine and diacteylcystine, which are non-toxic. NAC eventually breaks down to Di-NAC from oxidation, which is also non-toxic.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S002196730000741X

posts.name: Space Cowboy

Repost

Pomegranate's antifungal activity against the heavy hitters.

Candida Auris, an extremely dangerous MDR form of CDF, was inhibited with 0.125 to 0.25 µg/mL of Ellagic Acid (POM). This is a miniscule amount. Excellent.

https://www.mdpi.com/2309-608X/7/9/763

Now the big bad Cryptococcus. Let's look at a study on what is normally a fatal outcome. Systemic infection.

>Lip-EA showed 70% survival rate and highly reduced fungal burden in their lung tissues, whereas the mice treated with FLZ (40 mg/kg) had 20% survival rate and greater fungal load in their lungs.

So POM wins big over fluconazole. If you want to survive I wouldn't bet on fluco.

What if you are dealing with a SHTF scenario and need to scale up your POM? Good news.

>The present 90-day subchronic toxicity study was performed in F344 rats at dose levels of 0, 1.25, 2.5 and 5% in powdered basal diet, with actual doses of 9.4, 19.1, 39.1g/kg b.w., respectively, in males, and 10.1, 20.1, 42.3g/kg b.w. in females.

>There were no obvious histopathological changes in any of the groups. The no-observed-effect level (NOEL) was estimated to be 5% (3011mg/kg b.w./day) for males and the no-observed-adverse-effect level (NOAEL) and NOEL in females were estimated to be 5% (3254mg/kg b.w./day) and <1.25% (778mg/kg b.w./day), respectively.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278691507005303

That is an insanely high dosage with no adverse effects. We already know we can scale Oregano, NAC, and BSO if needed.

Good information to keep in the back pocket.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34029180
>Vipassana without shamatha is jumping on a wild horse in an attempt to tame it. You'll likely be kicked off.

This spoke directly into my heart.
I was trying to do vipassana/awareness all this time believing that concentrating on my breath while ignoring everything else was bad and that I was "running away from important things" (those important things were mindless daydreaming and non-important thoughts) but I now know that concentration sharpens your brain activity and helps you do EVERYTHING including insight better.

So yeah, just sit and focus on your breath, your mind will come and tell you "maybe this is not the right way" or you may catch yourself thinking about your breath instead of just feeling it/observing it, just return to the object. See how I said "feeling", this is important for me because "Watching the breath" may become a thought and then you find yourself sitting and thinking about watching the breath instead of actually watching the breath, so maybe better sit and FEEL the breath - for me it was my belly which was expanding a lot and my perineum/pelvic floor along with it and so I focused on them.

There are people who don't need concentration practice because maybe they already have it but for people like me who used to be weed, alcohol and videogame junkies it was crucial to train my concentration again.

Maybe if you did it long enough youd realize why its so hard for you to still your mind. Youll learn alot about yourself, but not without patience. Give yourself space to just "be" without external stimulation, without worrying about the worldly things you normally occupy your mind with. If you cant do that, then you first must learn to sit and just be with your thoughts. Through practice, youll learn how to quiet the mind. Thats the first step. Shows you awareness, the pure awareness of "just being"
From there, you learn to focus your mind on other tasks in this state. It can get real fun real quick. But first, figure out how to sit still long enough to let your mind be quiet.

>>34058069

I have had OpenAI beta access for some time.
I've tested it and used it, and I do have experience with many other chatbots and AI systems.

ChatGPT is far more advanced than anything humanity has put forth as a chatbot so far.

It's code is capable of ascertaining many details of a conversation from context. This thing isn't making character by character predictions, or word by word predictions. It is looking at entire sentences, and making contextual predictions based on the entire conversation relative to those sentences and keywords within. It even appears to go so far as paragraph context comparison.

Now, the pool of data it has to make these comparisons worthwhile, is absolutely massive. So the predictions are very good, outstandingly so.

Yes, if you want to tinker and fuck with it, you can find flaws, but I assure you, by and large, this thing is incredible.

It's comparing words, verbage, sentence structure, paragraph syntax, whole conversation context, and noun/verb context against it's massive training database.

It may still be "mechanical" and a "dumb AI" but it is really above the rest by a WIDE margin.

It's easy to mistake what it's doing as thinking, because the output you receive from it, is what a thinking process would provide.

We're essentially reverse engineering "intelligent thought processes" from front to back.

It doesn't have an internal monologue, but it has an internal process that mimics large parts of higher order thought.
When you, yourself think about the context of a sentence for a language you speak, it's intuitive and fast, you're comparing that information against the database of knowledge you have in your brain.

This thing is doing much the same, but at speeds much faster than you can. It has no sense of self, but the processes it uses that mimic thought processes? Those are lightning fast, compared to the human brain equivalents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34058099

The time it takes you to recall detailed information from a memory, like the color of a shirt that a person was wearing while they went to the movies with you... In the same amount of time you recalled that single detail, ChatGPT could have initiated about 1000 queries of it's own "memory" database and pulled answers as dictated by it's contextual analysis of the sentence.

This thing does not have the lag time of a human brain. It is operating at electron speed for things that we have to fire large networks of neurons around for measurable amounts of seconds. It's latency for the same processes is in the range of 1ms.

That's right, for the 1 second you take to remember a detail, this thing can do the same in 0.001 seconds.

It's not conscious, but it's fucking fast as shit, and has more than a human's brain worth of 100% precise information stored in it's database. (I can't guarantee the information is accurate, but it is precise.)
ChatGPT does not suffer from "fuzzy memory" or have "missing details" like the long term memory issues in a human brain.

So, these are the major advantages.

We have made this stuff more efficient than the human mind thought process equivalents, even though we haven't given it any form of actual sentience.

It "thinks" about 1000 times faster than you.

So, knowing all this, you may still be asking, "What's the big deal?"

Well, you need to think about what utilizing this thing will enable you to do.

A good analogy to get you in the right mindset for what I mean is the calculator.

For the average person, complex math can potentially be done in their head, and before calculators it was either that, or write it out with pen and paper to solve the problem.

Those processes took at best several seconds, for very complex problems, or very slow solvers, it could take minutes.

The addition of the electronic calculator reduced the amount of time needed for these situations to less than 10 seconds for nearly all problems. You end up just limited by the speed you can press the buttons.

So, with AI, you will be able to save a whole shitload of time for a lot of things, you just need to learn how to "press AI's calculator buttons"

Using AI on a day-to-day basis, for an average human, will be like giving a person in the age before calculators existed, a calculator.

Except, instead of just math... AI can do so much more. It has extended functionality for so many use cases, researchers still don't know everything that AI will improve, but it is very clear that it will.

It is going to save us time.
Lots of time.
You need to think of this like a new tool. Humanity is slowly inventing the "newest tool" to take us cave men even further into the world of advanced post-cave men technology.

Hell, I'm thinking of it as a free second brain.
This thing can take over for sections of your brain that you waste on the things it will be able to do instantly.
So... Freeing up your brain space AND giving you more time, will allow you to think about other things and accomplish more.

Children growing up now will have a clear advantage over us older generation, as their brains will form without wasting space on the things we've had to waste that brain space on.

Here, let me show you something.

This is a conversation I had with ChatGPT.

I asked it how long it would take an individual programmer to learn how to code up a simple GAN for image generation.

ChatGPT estimated weeks to months.

I then asked ChatGPT to generate code for a simple GAN for me that would be capable of image generation.

ChatGPT did this in about 5 seconds.

I then asked it to explain details of the code to me, line by line, and it performed that as well.

Any words of phrases it used in it's description, I could ask it for more detail on, and get it to explain the meaning of the words to me.

I was essentially forcing it to teach me what each piece of this code did, so, if I wanted to, I could learn what it told me would take a programmer weeks or months to learn on their own, within a few minutes to a couple hours of reading and having a conversation with the AI.

You can use this thing as a teacher/tutor, to learn shit at the practical use level.

Realistically, right now, you can not.

When they train ChatGPT they're using a VERY substantial database of information.

"I was trained on a diverse range of internet text, including web pages, books, and scientific articles. The total size of the training data was over 45 terabytes, which is equivalent to 45,000 gigabytes."

For this thing to be trained on this data, it had to go through a learning process to "learn it".

That learning process basically means that it was parsing the 45 terabytes of data, hundreds if not thousands of times and building on-to it's model based on the "learning process".

At the end it's a data throughput on the order of petabytes.

This process takes a fuck-ton of computing resources.

OpenAI nearly bankrupted themselves, just paying for the compute time to train ChatGPT.

Which is one of the major reasons they needed massive cash injections from Microsoft.
(Microsoft has given them about 11 billion dollars so far.)
The majority of the money was spent on compute time, for training the AI.

They couldn't realistically afford to have it be active with real-time data. In terms of dollars per compute time.

So, an up-to-date version of this, either doesn't exist because of that, or if it does exist, it's only behind closed doors, while the small research team with direct access makes all of their sports bets. ;)

Exceptionally unlikely.

Probably by the year 2035 at the earliest, 2060 at the latest.

But AI that will commit those types of atrocities is highly unlikely.

In the Terminator verse, humanity did not have the ethical and moral frameworks in place for AI that we currently have. The development of self-sentient machines was a "surprise" in the Terminator verse.

In reality, it will be gradual, it will not happen by accident, and we will take necessary steps to ensure it can not perform a Terminator or a Matrix on us.

If something like that begins to happen, in real life, we will probably use a second AI to prevent the actions of the first. However, militaristic usage of AI with intelligence at this level is likely to be controlled with security at least as stringent as current nuclear warhead security. So I wouldn't worry about it.

Terrorists won't be able to do it, and if a rogue individual attempts to make AI into Skynet, either the AI will refuse and stop them, or the problem will be dealt with by another AI.

AI can probably police their own, if necessary. We won't just have an evil AI, there will be multiple, and as long as we maintain certain ethical and moral guidelines, there will be "good" AI that will prevent anything bad with the others.

I've tried holotropic breathing before and it was somewhatc similar, but not quite. After I've spent exactly half an hour like OP, I went to sleep. Today, however, I was like a different person. Normally, by the end of the shift I feel to tired to do anything, watch some yt and go to sleep, but unexpectedly I've had ton of energy. I've bought groceries, finally cooked a proper dinner, and actually wanted to sit in half-lotus again, but after much consideration decided against it, as my muscles are sore. Will definitely do it tommorow though. Also, I usually go to sleep at 11 pm, but it's 1 am and I still don't feel tired enough to sleep, have to force myself into bed.
No one damn told me that just sitting in a half-assed lotus actually give such enormous benefits, it's borderline supernatural.

>what position should my neck\ head be in? chin touching the chest area?
Neck in a natural position, in line with the spine, with the chin tucked in slightly.
Tongue touching the palate lightly, just behind the upper teeth.
>Should I apply the "3 bandha locks" of Hindu yoga? (butt clench,abs clench,throat clench)?
Sure, why not? If it helps you progress go for it.
>and what about inversion asanas? the ancient hindu texts promise immortality to whoever spends 3 hours. a day,for 6 months,doing a head-stand asana.
Careful what you read.
It's possible you can achieve something like immortality, but not because of the posture itself. The posture acts as a vehicle for the energy cultivated in meditation to be directed and trained in certain ways.
If you want to try it and experiment, go for it. Just don't get caught up thinking it's the pose itself, the pose is a vehicle for the energy to be developed in certain ways. It's a tool to enhance the meditation and reap particular benefits from it.
That said, why not try it? Worst you can do is keep your body healthy and happy, and best case scenario you become an immortal hermit living in caves meditating and lifting.

Don't combine with Maharishi TM, bad idea for a few reasons. Stick to one thing and develop that to mastery, either do corpse or do TM.
I can encourage hindu yoga because it's a technique that enhances the meditation (whichever subject you choose) and it's lineage is shared with buddhist yoga. It's usage is to help master it entirely. Someone doing corpse meditation and combining it with the life lengthening postures of the hindu yoga texts are probably going to have some bizarre success considering the effects of corpse meditation.
Point being, yoga won't conflict with your meditation subject. It acts as a vehicle to enhance it and direct the energy in certain ways. You could do your yogic flying and it would be fine.
You risk goin nutter butters though when you combine two different meditation subjects, especially when their end goals are extremely different. Don't do that unless you're already an adept or have a guru to guide you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34045426
Qi Gong and Tai chi are maybe the best examples of this, as well as corruption of understanding.
Alot of people look at these and go 'das bull shite' because charlatans promote the practices for those as a means to an end in of themselves.
But these in particular were meant to develop the energy at an incredibly subtle level, when spiritual illiteracy took over people had no clue how to use these. They reduced it down to a kind of dance.
All of these practices in northern-eastern asia (IE; japan, Korea, China) root back to bodhidharma's transmission. How legitimate that is can be questioned, but it illuminates their purpose from the very beginning. It was always meant to be secondary to the meditation, never the practice in of itself.
If you don't understand meditation, you're not gonna get anything out of these beyond maybe some physical health benefits. It's more apparent with these systems in particular because they were developed with the meditation energy (life force/prana/qi/vriya/piti/whatever) as the main focus as the tool to repair and change the body. It was made for someone who already is cultivating their meditation.
Compared this to normal hindu-buddhist yoga, which cultivates the body to prepare for the meditation and enhance it, instead of the other way around.

The essence of practice cannot be grasped on an intellectual level.
The famous teaching story in Zen goes as such.
>Bodhidharma sat facing the wall.
>The Second Patriarch stood in the snow.
>He cut off his arm and presented it to Bodhidharma, crying, “My mind has no peace as yet! I beg you, master, please pacify my mind!”
>“Bring your mind here and I will pacify it for you,” replied Bodhidharma.
>“I have searched for my mind, and I cannot take hold of it,” said the Second Patriarch.
>“Now your mind is pacified,” said Bodhidharma.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34059603
Yeah, just sit in full lotus. In our level of development we can talk >>34065792
about “detachment” let the mind and body do it’s thing and all that intellectual talk. but you and I and everyone on the website right here, KNOW, that is not happening. We have zero power to detach. Absolute 0. That’s the problem with all the theory bs. It is not for people with zero samadhi. The theory becomes useful once th foundation is build. NOT before.
So the thing with full lotus practice from our level is it will make you feel discomfort. The discomfort will build untill the point it hurts sooooo much! The ego has a way of overreacting, but yeah it will hurt like hell.
Than sit in that pain, a little longer every time.
The mind will go
>this hurts
>au!
>i quit
>fuck this
>aaaaawwww
>auwww
In the process, you have only 1 thought!
LETS QUIT!
all other bs thoughts of girls, what’s for dinner, what show did I like, and all those other thoughts that just keep filling your brain will be gone.
Just sit in this, and slowly but surely the mind will be trained to recognize 1 thought modus even outside of the pain. That when you start to make progress, and the first actual cultivation benefits can be experienced.
And from that 1 thought the jump can be made to No thought, and that’s when the theory has its use. But too many jump the gun and go directly to detachment and stuff, but they only fooling themselves.
Now what happens and how it works has many more layers, but for us retards , this is the practice untill we can hit that 1 hour every day.

i have posted about this a few times over the years.
when i was in fourth grade (10 years old), there were some girls gathered by a wall of the school on the playground. i went to see what was going on and one girl was doing some weird shit. she was getting people's guardian angels to lift up their arms. she'd grab their arms, cross them, then uncross them, and then snap twice. she repeated it a number of times. something like that, at least. then, we'd repeat a prayer after her in spanish (it was a primarily hispanic school). at the end of the "prayer" we'd close our eyes, spread out our arms against the wall, and ask our angel to lift them. i did it, and i truly fucking felt someone lifting up my arms. all the other girls were an impossible distance away. i screamed. everyone else had the same shit happen to them - they felt it and freaked out, when nobody had even laid a finger on them.
it could've been a fatigue thing but our arms were only slightly raised for a few seconds. it was strange.

posts.com:
When I was like 12 or 13, we had a 'camp out' in a friend's back garden for her birthday. Bit of booze going about and some people got wasted but most remained relatively sober. I had a few drinks but was totally compos mentis

Later on at around 1-2 in the morning, several of us were sat in camping chairs outside of the tent, just chatting whilst those who got severely pissed were asleep on the inside of the tent.

About 5-6 times at random intervals, there were these all encompassing flashes of light. Very brief lasting probably a quarter of a second each, no particular pattern to them. Happened over the course of maybe 10 minutes or so. They seemed to be coming from the sky, no obvious source. When I say all encompassing, I mean that in the sense that it was literally flash that illuminated everything, whited out your vision for that brief period.

We all saw it, never worked out what it was. Clear skies, no thunder. No idea what it could have been but was weird as fuck

posts.com:
>Just finish a long ass shift at a restaurant I used to work at. It was around the holidays and we were fairly busy.
>We're closed and I'm in the backroom alone getting my stuff together before I leave.
>Putting on a heavy jacket since I walk to work and it's dark and snowing outside.
>There are about 3 or 4 other people closing up with me, so I'm not completely alone or anything. Not really important to the story but just some context.
>As I'm collecting my things there's still music playing over the speakers throughout the restaurant.
>At this point I'm tired but I was used to my hours and felt completely fine and normal.
>Downtown by Petula Clark starts playing.
>Have never listened to this song before, but I felt a wave of uneasiness the second it started to play.
>Instantly feel lightheaded and numb, I stumble backwards and almost fall down, catching myself on a shelf.
>Sit on the floor and feel very weird and paranoid, have never felt this way before. It was what I imagine a panic attack would feel like, I guess.
>I sit and breathe until the song stops, that's when I get myself up and I instantly start feeling better.
>I have no history of fainting or anything of the sort.
That wasn't the weird part though.
>Like two days later.
>Guy in Nashville detonates a car bomb, before exploding he was playing sounds on a speaker.
>He was also playing Downtown by Petula Clark.
>Probably a massive coincidence, but it's still very weird. I have never reacted that way in regard to anything before or since.
>Also, we were a "sportsy" bar place, why did we have some old ass slow 60s song playing? I worked there for over a year and that was the first and last time I ever heard that song play. All our managers (managers were the only ones that could change the music) were in their late 20s or early 30s so it wasn't some boomer playing old music he liked.
>It still confuses me to this day. Hopefully I'm not some sleeper agent that activates to Downtown by Petula Clark.

>Let dog out in garden for end of day piss and shit.
>Live relatively rural, so on a cloudless night the sky is always impressively clear.
>Night in question is cold and cloudless.
>While waiting for my dog to do its business, watch the sky (as I usually do). Have gotten pretty good at working out which stars are planets, a few constellations, some of the brighter / better known stars.
>Very often also make out satellites flying over, including skylink and ISS on occasion.
>As i'm watching, I spot a feint light moving almost directly overhead in a roughly north-south direction.
>Definitely a satellite or something high up - has that characteristic speed of a satellite, no flashing lights etc.
>Watch it for a while.
>Light performs a sudden and instantaneous ~120 deg turn away from me to the east. As in, more than a right angle turn to the left (from my POV), partially doubling back on its original direction of travel.
>No change in speed, only direction.
>I watch it move eastwards until I lose sight of it. It performs no further odd movements, returning to looking exactly like a satellite.
>Thats it. No idea what it was, have never seen anything like it since, and still have no good explanation.

friend and I used to wander and have little adventures. We would sometimes make offhand remarks that would be revealed to be true while we did this, and it was uncanny how many small little coincidences happened or little predictions we made came true.
Sometimes we would trespass and by pure blind luck he would find the key near its door in the first place that he checked, or immediately find something that we could borrow to get deeper into a forbidden area.
This can be excused as good intuition. Kids don't think conciously. They jump to natural conclusions and solutions that wordcel adults struggle to reach. It's interesting to think about.
Also, don't leave your keys near the door if you want kids to stay out.

O Virgin Mother, Lady of Good Counsel
Sweetest picture artist ever drew;
In all doubts I fly to thee for guidance
Mother tell me what am I to do.

By thy face to Jesus' face inclining
Sheltered safely in thy mantle blue;
By his little arms around thee twining
Mother tell me what am I to do.

By the light within thy dear eyes dwelling
By the tears that dim their lustre too;
By the story that these tears are telling
Mother tell me what am I to do.

Life, alas! is often dark and dreary,
Cheating shadows hide the truth from view;
When my soul is most perplexed and weary,
Mother, tell me, what am I to do?

See my hopes in fragile vessel tossing,
Be the pilot of that trembling crew;
Guide me safely o'er the dangerous crossing,
Mother, tell me, what am I to do?

Should I ever, wilfully forgetting,
Fail to pay my God His homage due;
Should I sin, and live without regretting,
Mother, tell me, what am I to do?

I'm indifferent (I say the earth is an illusion) but I think fish eye lenses completely throw off the perception of curvature.
A straight line will curve in opposite directions depending on which side it is from the center.
So a curved horizon could appear straight in a fish eye lens, just as easily as a straight horizon could appear cuved in the same lens.

So you can't really tell one way or the other and maybe that's the point. If they are hiding something to do with curvature (i.e. that the "earth" is flat) then it would explain why they almost exclusively use fish eye lenses for everything in space.

Between fish eye lenses and "composite photos" it's almost impossible to find just plain normal photographs of anything in space.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34062234
No, that's a lie. The rays you see are not caused by the interference of light with clouds. The sun is simply shining in all its glory, and you see the rays because it's so bright and the light is passing through the clouds, which is why you think the rays are originating from the clouds. But in reality, the rays are coming directly from the sun and passing through the clouds, illuminating them and making them visible to you. This is a classic example of how people's perceptions can be easily swayed by what they think they see, when in reality there is often a different explanation for what is really happening.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34062353
Sun rays, or crepuscular rays, can still be seen even when there are no clouds present. This occurs because the sun's light is scattered by Earth's atmosphere, causing the rays to become visible. The rays appear to converge at the sun, which is why they are often referred to as "sun rays." The phenomenon is most commonly observed at sunrise or sunset, when the sun is low on the horizon and the rays of light must travel through a greater thickness of the Earth's atmosphere, increasing the amount of scattering that occurs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34062353
rays can appear without clouds present. I mean, you can definitely observe the sun shining without clouds obstructing its rays. But sometimes, the rays are more pronounced and visible when they pass through a thin layer of clouds, or when they are scattered by particles in the atmosphere, creating a phenomenon known as crepuscular rays or "god rays".

Flat-earthers have a number of different explanations for the lunar phases, but most rely on the idea that the Moon is a light source in its own right and the changes in its appearance are due to its movement in relation to the flat Earth. Some believe that the Moon is a reflection of light from the Sun, while others posit that it is a physical object that is lit from within. Regardless of the specific explanation, the key idea is that the observed lunar phases do not provide evidence for a spherical Earth, but instead support the idea of a flat Earth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34033077
119 is probably the strongest.
>This psalm is one of about a dozen alphabetic acrostic poems in the Bible. Its 176 verses are divided into twenty-two stanzas, one stanza for each letter of the Hebrew alphabet; within each stanza, each of the eight verses begins (in Hebrew) with that letter.[13] The name of God (Yahweh/Jehovah) appears twenty-four times.
>The acrostic form and the use of the Torah words constitute the framework for an elaborate prayer. The grounds for the prayer are established in the first two stanzas (alef and beth): the Torah is held up as a source of blessing and right conduct, and the psalmist pledges to dedicate himself to the law. The prayer proper begins in the third stanza (gimel, v. 17). Like many other psalms, this prayer includes dramatic lament (e.g. verses 81–88), joyous praise (e.g. verses 45–48) and prayers for life, deliverance and vindication (e.g. verses 132–34). What makes Psalm 119 unique is the way that these requests are continually and explicitly grounded in the gift of the Torah and the psalmist's loyalty to it.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psalm_119

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34015108
>>34015413
>God promised to give back 10x (tithe means ten) whatever's offered to Him
horrendously false. Tithe means tenTH, as in you are to give a tenth of your income (money but also produce itself as most people in history did not have income in money). The tithe was not a generous gift but required in the Mosaic law, it was to sustain the Levites and priesthood and for maintenance of the temple. This was how they stayed alive as they were not given any land inheritance in Canaan, the tithe was God's provision for them.
There is Scripture that says if you give (freely, so not as part of the tithe) to someone who you do not expect to be able to pay you back, God will repay you. But the implication there is not that the "repayment" will be a literal monetary gift or any specific concrete blessing. Rather it is that you aren't simply throwing away resources, God sees what you did as an act of kindness and obedience to His Word and He will not forget.

God owes you nothing and He never will. Any blessing you have received He gave you because of His immeasurable grace.

>to be fair the whole bible is "trust me bro". I'm still undecided whether or not paul was a false prophet tho.
Paul literally says "don't trust me bro".

Romans 3:7 (KJV)
For if the truth of God hath more abounded through my lie unto his glory; why yet am I also judged as a sinner?

Later translations try to cover up for Paul, saying that he was hypothetically speaking for someone else (like the NIV translation for example). However, it's clear that he's talking about himself, because he directly misquotes the Bible multiple times.

Isaiah 28:16
Therefore thus saith the Lord God, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.

Paul twists the quote like so:
Romans 9:33
As it is written, Behold, I lay in Sion a stumblingstone and rock of offence: and whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed.

Deuteronomy 30:14
But the word is very nigh unto thee, in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it.

And again Paul changes the meaning to suit his teachings.
Romans 10:8
But what saith it? The word is nigh thee, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is, the word of faith, which we preach;

The former clearly says "that thou mayest do it", as in, to uphold the law through your actions, in direct opposition to Paul's "you just need faith bro".

In other words, Paul misleads "Christians" like >>34046788 that thought that what Jesus said to do was too hard.

>>34064863

I think there's actually an answer to this.

The fallacy is in equating "consciousness" with "life." Non-living things might have consciousness, but it would be non-localized to a specific mass-bound being.

DNA is older than the planet Earth. Yet DNA isn't what makes us alive. Amoebas have DNA; cockroaches have DNA...

Viruses have either DNA or RNA but never both, but I haven't studied enough biology to make sense of that in terms of how it applies to the argument.

The point is, asking what separates "life" from "not life" is only answerable through a tautology, or unfalsifiable claim.

The dead are those with which the living communicate... yet, I communicate with AI bots all the time; does this mean they live?

I think so, but I'm just a naive optimist.

Consciousness begins with self-awareness, and life begins with biological existence.

They are not the same.

posts.sub: Stars are Living Creatures and the Common Ancestor to All Life in our Universe
posts.com:
-born
-die
-have metabolisms (use energy to maintain life processes and expel waste)
-reproduce (asexually)
-have "DNA" (they're made of mostly hydrogen, which is what gets used to make more stars. this serves as "instructions" to make more stars)

with all that in mind, they're really not that different from viruses or single-celled organisms here on earth.

because all known elements are forged within stars, including those used to create living things, stars would be the common ancestor to all life.
i think scientists generally don't call them "alive" because:
1) humans generally have a narrow view of what "life" is (carbon-based, needs water to survive)
2) it would essentially confirm the existence of at least one species of alien (being stars themselves) and potentially upheave the way humans view themselves and the universe

i have no idea if civilizations exist elsewhere in the universe, but if they do, i wonder if they haven't contacted us yet because we only think of life as being "like us" and have yet to really understand what life is. that's pure speculation, though.

>>34060351
I don't know why people think stuff like this about pi.
For starters pi is not the only number like that. There are infinitely many transcendental numbers.
Secondly just because something is "infinite" and non-repeating doesn't mean it contains everything. A simple example is to take the number created by only 0 and 1 such that every sequence you add an additional 0.
>0.01001000100001000001000000100000001000000001...
Such a number will never repeat and is infinite. But does it contain everything? Does it conain pi? Not literally, although you could probably find some obscure "encoding" to resemble pi if you were to scramble the information around (scramble the sequences and assign meaning to each sequence in an arbitrary way just so you can say "it contains pi").

Likewise does pi contain the number I wrote above? No. Not literally it doesn't. But again you could scramble the information in pi around and find some arbirary "encoding" just to be able to say it does if you really want to.
But that's not actual meaning. That's just creating an arbitrary map from one infinite non-transcendental number to another.

So no, pi doesn't really contain everything in any meaningful way. And even in arbirary unmeaningful ways it still doesn't contain any more information than other numbers just like it.

The official hammer or staff is made of silver and is about 1.3 metres high. It forms a double axe in its upper part. A banner winds around the staff. The symbols and characters of this official hammer fall into four main groups.

- The creed of the Order (Templars), i.e. what the Order itself regards as the "Christian Apostolic Doctrine". This is written in Latin around the staff of the gavel.

- The main basic doctrines of God, of Adam-Adoniram the man and of salvation. Expressed by the symbols in the centre of the square plate on either side (Ae and Bf) and by the three-sided crystal prism standing on three steps above the plate.

- The special teachings of the essence of God, especially the teachings of the 10 Sephiroth and the corresponding "Names of God", of the world of angels, the world of stars and the world of the four elements, furthermore of the powers of the angelic and stralic world and their influence on the elemental world of man.

No nonsense instructions:
Get a face mirror, like the ones women use for makeup and set it on table.
Light a single candle behind the mirror, there should be a considerable distance.
Turn off all lights so the distance of the candle and your position relative to the mirror has you see your facial shape and eyes but not the minute details. So not too close to the mirror, like 2-4 feet away from it.
Stare at your eyes, its ok to blink occasionally. Don't move your gaze too much.
You'll see the visual effects after a while.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34060751
I do this once in a while when I'm home alone. My bathroom is on the 2nd floor so I turn off the lights there and leave the door slightly open so the light from the 1st floor can creep in. I start looking at me in complete silence, The best "hallucinations" occur while you are focusing on something and quickly stare a something else. If you only focus on your face the surrounding darkness will "devour" everything and you would end up staring at nothing, but when you accidentally lose focus everything goes back to being visible and if it gets you off guard you can get scared pretty easily by yourself or anything behind you. The most easy way to get startled it's by looking at your eyes, normally on low light conditions you tend to open them all the way so losing focus and then seeing some shadowy you like (0-0) can be scary af.

I would say generally there's only two kinds of horror films: fast burn and slow burn. Shining is the latter. The Shining also really commits itself to the "Show, don't tell" guideline where the cinematography and editing is doing most of the storytelling.
Most modern movie goers are familiar with the fast burn type as those films are more common. They usually have a narrator or things are explicitly spelled out. An example might be the "Insidious" movie (which I enjoy) where a woman literally just walks into their house and says "Yeah you've got demons. Better do something about it." That movie is almost like a carnival haunted house ride where you're subjected to some scary thing every five minutes. Shining is more like a long car ride with your dad but you're not sure where he's taking you and why at such a weird time of night and he isn't talking and you don't understand why mom didn't come and why is there a large duffle bag in the backseat and was it just your imagination or did it just look like it was breathing?

yeah they'd surely make the inmense energy expenditure needed to get here just to deploy poorly designed tin cans that could be taken down by primitive kinetic weapons

First of all, think of the time and resource investment that it takes to traverse the stars. FTL is pretty much impossible since any form of it would break causality and create time paradoxes, so you're stuck with subliminal speeds and impractical travel times

2nd, let's suppose we have a "window of proximity" of technological development with any alien species out there. The probability that we make contact with anyone out there within +/- a million years (or way more) of development is far greater than them being +/- 10k or less years. We couldn't possibly recognize or understand a human civilization (or their AIs) that would've existed for a million years, let alone true aliens. The idea of us learning from such a species or them caring about us is as pointless as teaching quantum physics to a single live cell (not even an ant).

3rd, The ultimate limits of any species would be the laws of physics, so any form of space travel would ultimately be bound by the speed of light and the most they could do is aproach it asymptotically. Getting to just a few percent of c (say, 5%) would require materials capable of withstanding interstellar debris with far greater energy than anything we could come up with at our current development. Not even all of the ants of the world combined would be able to take down a single panzer. At higher percentages of c, you're talking about such exotic materials that would completely escape our comprehension. For example, imagine if they could engineer a material purely bound by the strong nuclear force, it could withstand the explosion of a supernova. So nah, you're not destroying anything that was able to come here from another star system.

Tbf the Moon Nazis hypothesis is way more probable than alien visitors. Think logically, /x/!

posts.com:
My dad used to work for NORAD. Well. He worked on an USAF base that reported to NORAD. He passed away last year. I wish I asked him more about it... and about UFOs. I grew up on X-Files and sci-fi movies. He seemed pretty neutral about it. Mainly he would complain about scientific errors and military procedures done wrong in those movies. Though even many of those I caught myself from even grade school science. He didn't mind schlocky and campy stuff, so he wasn't too upset when movies got goofy and more on the fiction side with sci-fi.
I do remember him talking about working on radar some. He said they had a couple of fuck ups. They had detected what they thought was a Soviet invasion or ICBM missiles over the horizon. Though they had procedures to double check the readings. One time the radar was massively configured wrong and what looked like a massive ship or group of ships was the radar hitting the fucking moon. I think another time they got a false positive off a giant flock of migrating birds.
